definitions: cause something to become damaged useless or no longer fresh especially food
treat someone especially a child with excessive kindness that damages their character
examples: The hot weather will spoil the milk if left outside
Don't let the meat spoil by leaving it unrefrigerated
His grandparents spoil him by giving him everything he wants
She spoils her cat with expensive treats and toys daily

definitions: wipe or clean something using a soft porous material that absorbs water
get money food or other things from people without working or paying
examples: She sponged the spilled juice off the kitchen counter carefully
The nurse gently sponged his forehead to reduce the fever
He's been sponging off his parents for years without getting a job
Stop trying to sponge money from your friends all the time

definitions: create a humorous imitation of something serious to make people laugh
trick someone by making a fake version of something that seems real
examples: The comedy show spoofed popular movies from the eighties brilliantly
They spoofed the presidential debate with hilarious accuracy last night
Hackers spoofed the email address to steal personal information illegally
Someone spoofed my phone number to make fraudulent calls yesterday

definitions: cause someone or something especially an animal to become suddenly frightened
work as a spy gathering secret information for a government agency
examples: The loud noise spooked the horses causing them to run away
Don't make sudden movements that might spook the wild deer
He spooked for the intelligence agency during the cold war
She was recruited to spook on foreign diplomats in the embassy

definitions: wind thread wire or tape onto a cylindrical device for storage or use
examples: She carefully spooled the fishing line onto the reel before casting
The machine automatically spools the cable for efficient storage later

definitions: use a utensil with a shallow bowl to eat or serve food
lie close together with one person's back against another's front intimately
examples: The baby is learning to spoon cereal into her mouth independently
He spooned sugar into his coffee while reading the morning paper
The couple spooned on the couch while watching their favorite movie
They spooned all night to stay warm in the cold tent

definitions: direct a bright beam of light onto someone or something on stage
bring public attention to something important that needs to be noticed
examples: The technician spotlighted the lead singer during her solo performance
They spotlighted each dancer as they performed their individual routines
The documentary spotlights the urgent need for climate change action
The investigation spotlighted corruption within the city government system

definitions: cause liquid to flow out in a strong stream from an opening
talk continuously about something in a boring or annoying way
examples: Water spouted from the broken pipe flooding the basement quickly
The whale spouted water high into the air near our boat
He spouted nonsense about conspiracy theories for hours at dinner
She spouted poetry quotes whenever anyone would listen to her

definitions: injure a joint by twisting it suddenly causing pain and swelling
examples: She sprained her ankle while hiking on the rocky mountain trail
Be careful not to sprain your wrist playing tennis too aggressively

definitions: sit or lie with arms and legs spread out in a relaxed way
spread over a large area in an uncontrolled or unattractive manner
examples: The teenagers sprawled on the grass enjoying the warm summer sun
He sprawled across the entire couch leaving no room for others
The city continues to sprawl into the surrounding farmland every year
Suburban developments sprawl across what used to be natural forests

definitions: cause liquid to fly through the air in tiny drops or particles
apply liquid to something using a device that produces fine droplets
examples: Ocean waves sprayed salty water across the boat deck constantly
The sprinkler sprayed water evenly across the entire front lawn
She sprayed perfume on her wrists before leaving for the party
The farmer sprayed pesticide on the crops to protect from insects

definitions: engage in an activity especially shopping or spending in an uncontrolled way
examples: They went on a shopping spree buying everything they saw downtown
The team celebrated their victory with an eating spree at restaurants

definitions: scatter small drops or particles of something over a surface area
rain very lightly with small drops falling gently from the sky
examples: She sprinkled chocolate chips on top of the vanilla ice cream
The chef sprinkled fresh herbs over the pasta before serving it
It started to sprinkle just as we began our outdoor picnic
The weather forecast says it will sprinkle throughout the afternoon today

definitions: run at full speed over a short distance using maximum effort
examples: The athlete sprinted the final hundred meters to win the race
She had to sprint to catch the bus before it left

definitions: produce new growth especially shoots or buds from a seed or plant
appear or develop quickly in large numbers or amounts
examples: The seeds sprouted after just three days in the warm soil
New leaves sprouted from the branches after the spring rain came
Coffee shops have sprouted on every corner in this neighborhood recently
Gray hairs started to sprout in his beard after turning forty

definitions: make someone or something smarter neater or more attractive in appearance
examples: She spruced up the living room before her guests arrived tonight
He spruced himself up with a haircut and new suit for the interview

definitions: dig up potatoes from the ground using a special tool or spade
examples: The farmers spudded their potato fields early in the morning
We need to spud the garden before the ground freezes this winter

definitions: encourage or prompt someone to do something or work harder
make a horse go faster by pressing sharp points into its sides
examples: The coach's words spurred the team to play their best game ever
Competition spurred innovation in the technology industry this past decade
The cowboy spurred his horse to escape from the approaching storm
She gently spurred the horse forward along the mountain trail

definitions: cause liquid to flow out suddenly in a quick strong stream
show a sudden brief increase in activity effort or speed
examples: Blood spurted from the wound before the nurse applied pressure
Water spurted from the fountain in rhythmic patterns all day long
The economy spurted briefly before returning to slow growth rates
She spurted ahead in the final lap to overtake her competitor

definitions: cry out loudly and continuously especially as a baby or young child
blow with strong winds usually during a brief violent storm
examples: The hungry baby squalled until her mother fed her warm milk
The infant squalled throughout the entire flight annoying other passengers
The wind squalled fiercely as the storm moved across the coastline
Dark clouds gathered and the wind began to squall dangerously

definitions: press something flat or into a smaller space by applying force
forcefully stop or prevent something from continuing or developing
examples: She accidentally squashed the tomato while unpacking the grocery bags
Don't squash the bread by putting heavy items on top of it
The government tried to squash the protests with police intervention
Her parents squashed her dreams of becoming a professional dancer

definitions: lower your body by bending your knees while keeping your back straight
live in a building or on land without permission from the owner
examples: She squats fifty times every morning as part of her exercise routine
The trainer showed them how to squat properly without injuring knees
Homeless people squat in the abandoned factory building during winter months
They've been squatting on that land for years without paying rent

definitions: make a loud harsh cry like a bird especially when frightened
complain or protest about something in a loud annoying way
examples: The parrot squawked loudly when strangers entered the pet store
Seagulls squawked overhead as they fought over pieces of bread
Customers squawked about the price increase at the town meeting yesterday
He always squawks when asked to do his share of housework

definitions: make a short high-pitched sound like a mouse or unoiled hinge
manage to achieve something but only by a very small margin
examples: The old door squeaked every time someone opened it slowly
Her new shoes squeaked on the polished floor of the museum
She squeaked through the exam with just one point above passing
The team squeaked past their opponents winning by a single goal

definitions: look at something with eyes partly closed to see better or because of bright light
examples: She squinted at the menu in the dimly lit restaurant
He had to squint in the bright sunlight without his sunglasses

definitions: accompany or escort someone especially a woman to a social event
examples: He squired his elderly mother to the charity gala last night
The young man proudly squired his date to the senior prom

definitions: cause liquid to be forced out in a thin fast stream from something
examples: The child squirted water from the toy gun at his friends
She squirted lemon juice on the fish before grilling it outside

definitions: thrust a sharp pointed weapon into someone or something to cause injury
make a sudden unplanned attempt to do something
examples: The attacker tried to stab him with a kitchen knife during the robbery
She accidentally stabbed her finger while cutting vegetables for dinner
Let me take a stab at solving this math problem myself
He took a stab at writing poetry but wasn't very successful

definitions: make or become unlikely to change fail or decline remaining firm and steady
examples: The doctor worked to stabilise the patient's blood pressure overnight
Government policies helped stabilise the economy after the financial crisis

definitions: make or become unlikely to change fail or decline remaining firm and steady
examples: Medication helped stabilize her mood swings within a few weeks
The new supports will stabilize the bridge during earthquake conditions

definitions: go to a social event without bringing a romantic partner or date
examples: He decided to stag it at his cousin's wedding reception
Many guests chose to stag the company holiday party this year

definitions: walk or move unsteadily as if about to fall from weakness or drunkenness
arrange events or activities so they happen at different times not together
examples: He staggered home after drinking too much at the celebration party
The injured player staggered off the field holding his head
The company staggers lunch breaks so the office stays open continuously
They staggered the race start times to avoid overcrowding at checkpoints

definitions: mark or discolor something with a substance that is hard to remove
damage someone's reputation or character with shameful or disgraceful actions
examples: Red wine stained the white tablecloth during the dinner party
Grass stains marked his jeans after playing soccer all afternoon
The scandal stained his reputation making it hard to find work
One mistake shouldn't stain her entire career in public service

definitions: become no longer fresh and pleasant to eat or smell typically of food
examples: The bread will stale quickly if you leave the bag open
Chips stale within hours once exposed to humid air conditions

definitions: bring to a position where no progress can be made by either side
examples: The negotiations stalemated when neither side would compromise on key issues
The chess match stalemated after both players ran out of winning moves

definitions: follow or approach someone persistently and secretly often to harm them
walk in a stiff angry or proud manner with deliberate steps
examples: The predator stalked its prey through the tall grass silently
A fan was arrested for stalking the celebrity to her home
She stalked out of the meeting after the unfair criticism
He stalked away angrily when he didn't get the promotion

definitions: stop running suddenly especially of an engine or vehicle
deliberately delay or prevent something from happening or progressing
examples: The car stalled at the intersection causing a traffic backup
The airplane engine stalled during takeoff requiring emergency procedures
He's stalling on signing the contract while negotiating better terms
Stop stalling and tell me what really happened last night

definitions: rush wildly in a mass panic especially of frightened animals or people
examples: The cattle stampeded when they heard the loud thunder crash overhead
Shoppers stampeded toward the doors when the store opened for sales

definitions: make things conform to a standard so they are all the same
examples: The company standardised its procedures across all international branches
Schools need to standardise testing methods for fair student evaluation

definitions: make things conform to a standard so they are all the same
examples: They standardized the manufacturing process to ensure product quality
The organization wants to standardize training across all departments

definitions: attach papers or materials together using small metal fasteners
examples: Please staple these documents together before filing them away
She stapled the receipt to the expense report for accounting

definitions: turn a ship or boat toward the right side when facing forward
examples: The captain ordered the crew to starboard to avoid the rocks
We need to starboard quickly to enter the harbor safely

definitions: make fabric stiff by treating it with a substance from plants
examples: She starched his dress shirts to keep them crisp and professional
The laundry starched the table linens for the formal dinner event

definitions: cause someone to feel sudden shock or alarm by an unexpected event
examples: The loud bang startled everyone in the quiet library reading room
Don't startle the baby by turning on bright lights suddenly

definitions: suffer or die from lack of food over an extended period of time
deprive someone or something of something necessary or very important
examples: Many people starve in regions affected by drought and war
The lost hikers nearly starved before rescue teams found them
Don't starve your plants of water during the hot summer months
The project starved for funding after investors pulled out suddenly

definitions: store something safely in a secret place for use in the future
examples: She stashed emergency money in a book on the shelf
The squirrel stashed acorns in the tree for winter food supply

definitions: stop or restrict the flow of blood from a wound
examples: The medic used pressure to staunch the bleeding from the injury
Quick action helped staunch the wound before the ambulance arrived

definitions: delay or prevent something bad from affecting you usually temporarily
examples: They managed to stave off bankruptcy with an emergency loan
Eating small snacks can stave off hunger between regular meals

definitions: control the direction of a vehicle by turning a wheel or handle
guide or direct the course of something toward a particular outcome
examples: She learned to steer the boat through narrow channels safely
It's difficult to steer on icy roads without proper winter tires
The counselor steered him toward a career in medicine
Let's steer the conversation away from controversial political topics tonight

definitions: produce a design by applying paint through a cut-out pattern
examples: She stenciled flowers on the bedroom wall for decoration
They stenciled their company name on all the shipping boxes
